newsitem.title: CHINA: China says troop reduction pact aid to world peace.
newsitem.headline: China says troop reduction pact aid to world peace.

text.p: China on Thursday hailed a new treaty with Russia and three central Asian nations to reduce troop levels along the former Soviet-Chinese border as playing a major role in promoting regional and world peace.

Chinese President Jiang Zemin, his Russian counterpart Boris Yeltsin, and the presidents of Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan signed the troop reduction pact in Moscow on Thursday, Russia's Itar-Tass news agency said.

"These five countries, through peaceful and friendly consultations, have taken an important step towards realising regional security... and world peace and stability," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Cui Tiankai said.
"This is a new kind of security outlook, under a new international situation that differs from Cold War mentality," Cui told a regular news briefing.
No details of the treaty have been disclosed, but the pact is a follow-up to an agreement on security-building measures along the border signed by leaders of the five nations last April in Shanghai.
"It is of major and far-reaching significance," Cui said.

Russia's Interfax news agency quoted Russian government experts as saying the pact would limit land forces, short-range aviation and anti-aircraft defence deployed in the 100-km-wide (63-mile) strip along the border, which stretches for more than 7,000 km (4,400 miles).
The pact, which also includes a system of mutual inspections to make the 100-km strip transparent, is to be ratified by the parliaments of the five signatories.
